intro: Codariocalyx microphyllus var. macrocarpus, commonly known as the large-fruited burr gourd, is a tropical vine native to Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its hairy, heart-shaped leaves and distinctive, spiny fruits that can grow up to 30 centimeters in length. The plant produces yellow flowers that develop into the characteristic burr-like fruits, which are used in traditional medicine and cuisine. Its rapid growth habit and adaptability make it a common weed in agricultural settings. Botanically, it belongs to the family Cucurbitaceae, which includes other economically important plants like cucumbers and pumpkins.
